body:
Not sure if I should change `Log.error` to `Log.warn` here: https://github.com/twitter/heron/pull/1336/files#diff-409c349551fd1e7ad3611d8544571cffR148

In my opinion, we should have different logging level for "Metrics not available" (`Log.warn`) and "Unknown component" (`Log.error`). However, we have no way to distinguish since we only have [`OK` and `NOTOK`](https://github.com/twitter/heron/blob/62793b63413976cc4f9d2e7cceb0815d062523d4/heron/proto/common.proto#L6). Maybe we can add another specific error number, like `METRICS_NOT_AVAILABLE`?
Thanks to @nlu90, we can close this via https://github.com/twitter/heron/pull/1317
üëç

üëç

Ugh, yeah that's the problem. The statemanager config loading is not in the shape I'd like it to be. The issue is that the python state managers take configs in a different format than the java state managers and we have configs for the latter so we need to read them and convert to the former.

We can't just read the configs directly, because the java impl has wildcard parsing logic not present in the python impl. For example, for the local statemanager the config is this:

```
$ grep heron.statemgr.root.path ~/.heron/conf/local/statemgr.yaml
heron.statemgr.root.path:                       ${HOME}/.herondata/repository/state/${CLUSTER}
```

where `${CLUSTER}` and `${HOME}` are not handled. What we need is a python implementation of https://github.com/twitter/heron/blob/master/heron/spi/src/java/com/twitter/heron/spi/common/Misc.java#L142

Anyone know if there's anything similar in python?

Command to run the snippet I posted:
clang++ -std=c++11 -stdlib=libc++ -Weverything main.cpp; ./a.out
üëç

@billonahill 

How about using [`os.path.split`](https://docs.python.org/2.7/library/os.path.html#os.path.split) to split path, substituting wildcard variable with corresponding variable in config, and finally using [`os.path.join`](https://docs.python.org/2.7/library/os.path.html#os.path.join) to join them back?
üëç
I'm going to take a stab at this. I suspect there are wildcard heron variables that we don't have access to in python like we do in java, but let me see how much we can support.
@mycFelix yeah üëç

`java.lang.Long.hashCode` was removed in Java 8.
Hmm, I still see it in java 8 actually.
Interesting... is it the other way around? I am trying this on Java 7
Yes, it is. It's `Long.hashCode(long value)` which was introduced in 1.8. We should change it to `longValue.hashCode()` which is 1.7 compliant.

## 

Andrew Jorgensen
@ajorgensen
üëç
üëç
Would you like to show your Heron version and more configurations?
üëç  @ashvina @avflor - do you have any comments on this?
@ashvina - if this is not needed, please close this.

to show heron version, do the following 

```
cmdline> heron version
```
@ashvina - can help with this?

@billonahill 
Is the user expected to configure ${HOME} in some config file? The path is getting resolved incorrectly:

```
 09/08/2016 22:31:45 -0700:INFO: Logging pid 50263 to file heron-executor-0.pid
 09/08/2016 22:31:45 -0700:INFO: Connecting to file state with rootpath: /home//.herondata/repository/state/yarn
 09/08/2016 22:31:45 -0700:INFO: Registered state watch for packing plan changes with state manager <heron.statemgrs.src.python.filestatemanager.FileStateManager object at 0x10f8db450>.
 09/08/2016 22:31:45 -0700:INFO: State watch triggered for packing plan change. New PackingPlan:
```
This was addressed in #1334 so closing.

@ashvina no ideally the user should have to. There are different ways to determine the home dir in python, we're using 

```
home_dir = os.getenv('HOME')
```

See https://github.com/twitter/heron/blob/master/heron/statemgrs/src/python/configloader.py#L29

We could change that approach though. Could you see if this resolves correctly in your environment:

```
from os.path import expanduser
home = expanduser("~")
```

@billonahill Thanks for the pointers.
This issue is similar to one seen in #1140. Many times YARN application is headless and there is no home directory for the user. Also it is possible the user launching the topology is different from the executor's user. In my test case, YARN set the home as /home. I can thinking of fixing the issue by updating the YARN configuration for now. But I am not sure if resolving the path on the executor is a good idea. What do you think about constructing the state manager directory location on the client and let all components use the same?

The `${HOME}` wildcard token is supported and used extensively by Heron in the java classes, as most files under https://github.com/twitter/heron/blob/master/heron/config/src/yaml/conf show. I don't think we should deviate from that approach just for the python statemanger use case. Yarn must be able to load this path currently for [java](https://github.com/twitter/heron/blob/master/heron/config/src/yaml/conf/yarn/statemgr.yaml#L8) so we should be able to do the same for python.
@kramasamy yeah, I compared the jars in WORKSPACE file with the old heron repo. Most of the used jars remain the same.
@billonahill I have addressed all the comments. Let me know if anything else is needed.
üëç  if we can make sure it also works in the headless-YARN application scenario


it give an idea what caused the failure.
